choices.text: Incidence refers to the total number of cases, while prevalence refers to the proportion of the population affected.
Incidence refers to the proportion of the population affected, while prevalence refers to the total number of cases.
Incidence measures new cases, while prevalence measures existing cases.
Incidence measures existing cases, while prevalence measures new cases.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between incidence and prevalence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Incidence measures new cases, while prevalence measures existing cases.

choices.text: To measure the economic productivity of a country
To assess the burden of disease by combining years of life lost due to premature mortality and years lived with disability
To evaluate the quality of life of individuals with disabilities
To estimate the number of years an individual can expect to live in good health

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of calculating HALE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

To estimate the number of years an individual can expect to live in good health

The primary purpose of calculating HALE is to estimate the number of years an individual can expect to live in good health.

choices.text: Reduce the Infant Mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

Reduce the stillbirth rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

questions.text: Which of the following is a target of SDG Goal 3 related to child health?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Reduce the under-5 mortality rate to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births by 2030

choices.text: Individuals who consume alcohol have a 2.5 times higher risk of liver disease compared to non-drinkers.
Alcohol consumption decreases risk of liver disease.
Liver disease leads to increased alcohol consumption.
There is no association between alcohol consumption and liver disease.

questions.text: A study is conducted to investigate the association between alcohol consumption and liver disease. The study finds a relative risk of 2.5. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Individuals who consume alcohol have a 2.5 times higher risk of liver disease compared to non-drinkers.

choices.text: The period during which a person is infectious to others.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The period from exposure to onset of symptoms.

choices.text: Agent, host, and environment.

questions.text: The "epidemiological triad" of disease consists of:
questions.solution:

Agent, host, and environment.

choices.text: It represents the total number of deaths in a population.
It measures the severity of a disease outbreak.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the case fatality rate (CFR)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is the ratio of deaths from a specific disease to the total number of cases of that disease.

choices.text: A disease that occurs at a consistent rate within a specific geographic area.

The complete eradication of a disease from a population.

questions.text: The term "endemic" refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A disease that occurs at a consistent rate within a specific geographic area.

questions.text: Eligible couple register is maintained by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

•	EC register is maintained by ANM at Subcenter level

questions.text: Which of the following is not a barrier method?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•	Barrier methods are those contraceptive method which prevents entry of sperm into female genital tract.

•	Barrier methods are of two types

•	Physical :  condoms, sponge, diaphragm

•	Chemical: spermicidal jellies, foams

choices.text: The rule that suggests dividing a patient's medication dosage in half to minimize side effects.
A guideline stating that half of the population will experience a certain health condition at some point in their lives.
A concept indicating that only half of the prescribed treatment or interventions for a condition are typically completed or adhered to by patients.

A principle suggesting that about half of the people with a particular health issue are aware of their condition, half of those who are aware seek medical care, and half of those who seek care receive adequate treatment.

questions.text: Which healthcare principle is described by the "rule of halves"?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A principle suggesting that about half of the people with a particular health issue are aware of their condition, half of those who are aware seek medical care, and half of those who seek care receive adequate treatment.

choices.text: It represents the recommended ages for cervical cancer screening - 90% of women should begin screening at age 70 and continue every 90 months thereafter.
It refers to the distribution of cervical cancer cases globally, with 90% occurring in women aged 70 and older, with a 90% survival rate.
It indicates the proportion of cervical cancer cases caused by HPV strains covered by current vaccines, with 90% coverage in women aged 70 and older.

It signifies the ideal performance of cervical cancer screening programs, aiming for 90% of eligible women to be screened, with 70% screened regularly and 90% of abnormal results followed up appropriately.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes the significance of the "90-70-90" pattern in cervical cancer screening?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It signifies the ideal performance of cervical cancer screening programs, aiming for 90% of eligible women to be screened, with 70% screened regularly and 90% of abnormal results followed up appropriately.

choices.text: It outlines strategies for maintaining mental health through stress management techniques recommended by the World Health Organization.
It is a framework developed by the World Health Organization for monitoring and assessing noncommunicable disease risk factors.
It provides guidelines for implementing hygiene protocols and infection control measures in healthcare settings, as recommended by the World Health Organization.
It focuses on promoting physical activity and exercise routines endorsed by the World Health Organization for combating obesity and sedentary lifestyles.

questions.text: Which statement best describes the WHO STEPS approach in public health?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It is a framework developed by the World Health Organization for monitoring and assessing noncommunicable disease risk factors.

choices.text: A physical barrier that separates different demographic groups within a population.
A period in a country's demographic transition where the proportion of working-age population is relatively high.
The statistical analysis of demographic data collected from various sources.
A government policy aimed at regulating population growth through incentives and disincentives.

questions.text: What does the term "demographic window" typically refer to in the context of population dynamics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A period in a country's demographic transition where the proportion of working-age population is relatively high.

choices.text: Antara is a male contraceptive pill designed to inhibit sperm production.
Antara is a brand of emergency contraceptive pill effective up to 72 hours after unprotected intercourse.
Antara is an intrauterine device (IUD) implanted in women to prevent pregnancy.
Antara is a progestin-only contraceptive injection administered every 12 weeks to prevent ovulation.

questions.text: Which statement accurately describes Antara contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antara is a progestin-only contraceptive injection administered every 12 weeks to prevent ovulation.

choices.text: Financial support for families planning to adopt children domestically.
Legal protection for individuals seeking family planning services.
Compensation for adverse effects resulting from family planning methods.
Educational resources for promoting family planning awareness nationwide.

questions.text: What does the National Family Planning Indemnity Scheme primarily aim to provide?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Compensation for adverse effects resulting from family planning methods.

choices.text: Iron deficiency anaemia
Vitamin D deficiency
Zinc deficiency

questions.text: What condition is most likely affecting a 6-year-old child presenting with poor growth, frequent infections, delayed wound healing, thin and brittle hair, and signs of dermatitis around the mouth?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Zinc deficiency

choices.text: The maximum amount of a nutrient that can be safely consumed daily without risk of adverse effects.
The average daily dietary intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group.
The minimum amount of a nutrient required to prevent severe deficiency symptoms in the general population.
The recommended amount of a nutrient to be consumed daily, regardless of individual differences or health conditions.

questions.text: According to Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) guidelines, what does the term "RDA" represent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The average daily dietary intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a specific life stage and gender group.

choices.text: Providing financial assistance for the construction of household toilets in rural areas.
Promoting awareness about the importance of maternal and child health through community education programs.
Offering financial incentives to pregnant women for delivering babies in healthcare facilities.
Ensuring access to free healthcare services for pregnant women and newborns in urban slums.

questions.text: What does JSY (Janani Suraksha Yojana) primarily aim to achieve?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Offering financial incentives to pregnant women for delivering babies in healthcare facilities.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, joint pain, and fatigue. Upon examination, a blue-black line is noted along the gingival margin, known as the Burtonian line. The patient works in a paint factory. What condition is most likely present in this patient, given the clinical findings and occupational history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lead poisoning

choices.text: Sensitivity = True Positive / (True Positive + False Positive)

Sensitivity = True Negative / (True Negative + False Positive)

questions.text: How is sensitivity calculated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sensitivity = True Positive / (True Positive + False Negative)

questions.text: Consider a dataset representing the heights of students in a class. The heights follow a normal distribution with a mean of 160 cm and a standard deviation of 10 cm. If a randomly selected student from this class has a height of 170 cm, what is the z-score for this student's height?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

+1.0

The average number of children a woman gives birth to during her lifetime.

choices.text: A study design that follows a group of individuals over time to observe the development of a disease.
A study design that compares individuals with a particular condition or disease (cases) to those without the condition (controls) to identify potential risk factors.
A study design that randomly assigns participants to different treatment groups to assess the effectiveness of an intervention.
A study design that collects information about a population at a single point in time to estimate prevalence rates of a disease.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a case-control study?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

A study design that compares individuals with a particular condition or disease (cases) to those without the condition (controls) to identify potential risk factors.
